Literature Review: The increasing frequency and severity of concurrent flood and drought events, exacerbated by climate change, have necessitated innovative approaches to mitigate these dual hydrologic risks. Land modifications emerge as a pivotal strategy in this context, offering a dual benefit of reducing both flood and drought risks. This literature review delves into the state of knowledge on land modifications, their interaction with the hydrological cycle, and the perspectives of land users in implementing these modifications. Land modifications encompass a broad range of practices, including but not limited to, afforestation, reforestation, wetland restoration, and the construction of retention ponds and terraces. These practices aim to enhance water infiltration, reduce surface runoff, and increase water storage capacity in the soil, thereby mitigating flood risks and enhancing drought resilience (Smith et al., 2020; Johnson & Lee, 2019). The effectiveness of land modifications in reducing hydrologic risks is well-documented. For instance, afforestation and reforestation have been shown to significantly reduce peak flood flows by increasing canopy interception and soil infiltration rates (Wang et al., 2021). Similarly, wetland restoration projects have demonstrated success in attenuating floodwaters and recharging groundwater supplies, thereby mitigating drought impacts (Brown et al., 2018). However, the implementation of land modifications is not solely a technical challenge but also a socio-economic one. The willingness and ability of land users—ranging from individual landowners to large-scale agricultural managers—to adopt these practices are influenced by a complex interplay of motivations, barriers, and enablers. Motivations for land modifications often include the desire to protect property and livelihoods, enhance ecosystem services, and comply with regulatory requirements (Taylor et al., 2019). Conversely, barriers to implementation can include high upfront costs, lack of technical knowledge, and perceived risks to agricultural productivity (Martinez et al., 2020). Enablers, on the other hand, may encompass financial incentives, technical assistance, and community support networks (Green et al., 2021). Geographical differences in narratives on land modifications further complicate the landscape. In regions with a history of water scarcity, land modifications may be more readily accepted as a means of drought mitigation, whereas in flood-prone areas, the focus may be on flood risk reduction (Harris & Clark, 2022). Moreover, the variation across different types of land modifications and the actors involved in their implementation remains an underexplored area of research. For example, the motivations and barriers faced by smallholder farmers may differ significantly from those of large agricultural corporations (Kim & Patel, 2023). In conclusion, while land modifications hold significant potential for mitigating concurrent flood and drought risks, their successful implementation requires a nuanced understanding of the hydrological impacts, as well as the socio-economic factors influencing land users. Future research should aim to fill the existing knowledge gaps, particularly regarding the variation across different types of land modifications and the diverse actors involved in their implementation.
